meta.title: Overview of protozoal infections and antiprotozals

content:
Introduction

Protozoa (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
) are microscopic unicellular eukaryotes found in most habitats worldwide.  They were first visualized in 1674 by Antonie van Leeuwenhoek using a single-lens microscope.  Protozoal infection can be commensal or pathogenic depending on the organism, the immune status of the host, and the prevalence of the protozoal organism within a region.  Protozoa often have complex lifecycles that include alterations in pathogen structure or host environment during different stages.  Treatment must be tailored to local resistance patterns and may require a species-specific medication.

Protozoal infections



Pathogenic protozoa are typically transmitted by the fecal-oral route or by insect bite (eg, mosquitos, ticks, bugs) (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
).  In humans, protozoal disease most commonly occurs in the intestines, bloodstream, or genitourinary tract; however, immunocompromised hosts are at risk for a wider array of illnesses by various protozoa, some of which may attack other organs (eg, lungs, brain).  A broad discussion of common protozoal illnesses in different organ systems follows.

Intestinal protozoa



Entamoeba histolytica (amebiasis)



  • Cysts are found in contaminated food/water and transmitted via the fecal-oral route.  They mature to trophozoites in the large intestine.
  • Patients develop acute or chronic diarrhea; mucosal invasion occurs in a minority of cases, leading to ulcers (eg, dysentery) and/or spread to other organs (eg, hepatic abscess).


Giardia duodenalis



  • Cysts are transmitted via the fecal-oral route in contaminated water (most often) and mature to trophozoites in the upper portion of the small intestine, leading to noninvasive infection.
  • Most patients are asymptomatic, but a minority develop watery, foul-smelling diarrhea, which is typically self-limited.


Cryptosporidium



  • Oocysts are found in contaminated food/water and are transmitted via the fecal-oral route.  They mature to sporozoites in the gastrointestinal tract and invade intestinal epithelial cells.
  • Many cases are asymptomatic, but infection may cause self-limited, acute diarrhea; patients with immunosuppression (eg, AIDS) are at risk for chronic, voluminous diarrhea.

Hematologic protozoa



Plasmodium (malaria)



  • Sporozoites (
    image 1
    ) are transmitted by female Anopheles mosquitoes, mature to merozoites in hepatocytes, and then spread to erythrocytes.
  • Patients develop a febrile, flu-like illness (eg, fever paroxysms, chills, headache, malaise, anemia) due to erythrocyte lysis; severe, life-threatening disease with multiorgan involvement (eg, brain, lungs, kidney) can occur.


Babesia



  • Sporozoites are transmitted by ticks (eg, Ixodes species) and mature into trophozoites/merozoites in erythrocytes.
  • Erythrocyte lysis causes flu-like symptoms; immunosuppressed individuals are at risk for severe disease with complications (eg, hemolytic anemia, acute respiratory distress syndrome, or congestive heart failure).

Genitourinary protozoa



Trichomonas vaginalis



  • Trophozoites are transmitted during sexual contact (there is no cyst stage).
  • Most patients are asymptomatic, but a minority develop vaginitis, vaginal discharge (purulent, malodorous, thin), and genitourinary symptoms (eg, burning, pruritus, dysuria).

Brain/tissue-invasive protozoa



Naegleria fowleri (primary amebic meningoencephalitis)



  • Trophozoites penetrate the olfactory epithelium during swimming, diving, or other activities in warm freshwater.
  • Infections are rare and characterized by a fulminant, rapidly progressive encephalitis.


Toxoplasma gondii



  • Transmission occurs via accidental ingestion of oocysts from cat feces (eg, in contaminated food or water), ingestion of tissue cysts in undercooked meat, or transplacental spread.  After ingestion, the pathogen differentiates into sporozoites (from oocysts) or bradyzoites (from tissue cysts), penetrates intestinal epithelial cells, and disseminates systemically via the bloodstream or lymphatics.
  • Most patients are asymptomatic, but a small minority develop lymphadenopathy (bilateral, symmetric, nontender cervical) or constitutional symptoms; immunosuppressed patients are at risk for life-threatening organ infection (eg, encephalitis, pneumonitis).


Trypanosoma cruzi (Chagas disease)



  • Trypomastigotes are transmitted when a triatomine  (kissing bug) defecates near a bite wound (classically located by the eye); the pathogen replicates intracellularly at the portal of entry (skin or mucous membranes) and then spreads systemically.
  • Acute infection is usually marked by systemic symptoms and localized swelling at the portal of entry; a minority of untreated individuals develop severe complications (eg, dilated cardiomyopathy, megaesophagus, megacolon) years later.


Trypanosoma brucei (African sleeping sickness)



  • Trypomastigotes are injected into the bloodstream during bites from the Tsetse fly (Glossina species); the pathogen replicates in blood, lymph, and interstitial fluid (does not invade cells).
  • Patients develop intermittent fever, lymphadenopathy, rash, and other systemic signs; late disease is marked by invasion of the blood-brain barrier with CNS manifestations (eg, behavioral changes, daytime sleep/nighttime insomnia, confusion, seizures).


Leishmania species



  • Promastigotes are transmitted by female sand flies and are subsequently phagocytosed by host macrophages; the pathogen replicates in macrophages.
  • Depending on the infecting species, patients may develop cutaneous (eg, painless skin ulcers at entry), mucocutaneous (spread to mucous membranes), or visceral (eg, pancytopenia, splenomegaly, death) illness.


Many protozoal infections become chronic or relapsing due to immune system evasion, latency, or persistence in immunologically privileged sites.  Disease severity is often exacerbated in immunocompromised hosts.

Antiprotozoals



Antiprotozoal agents are categorized based on their chemical structure and mechanism of action.  The major classes of antiprotozoal therapy are listed below.

Nitroimidazoles



Nitroimidazoles (eg, metronidazole, tinidazole) have activity against anaerobic bacteria and some protozoa (eg, Giardia, Entamoeba, Trichomonas).  They passively diffuse into the organism, and, in low-oxygen environments (eg, anaerobic conditions), the nitro group is reduced, leading to the generation of free radicals.  The free radicals break DNA strands, inhibit DNA synthesis, and destroy proteins, resulting in cell death.



Common adverse effects of metronidazole include a metallic taste and gastrointestinal upset (eg, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea).  Alcohol should be avoided during treatment and for 48 hours following the final dose due to the potential for disulfiram-like effects (flushing, nausea, vomiting, palpitations).  Prolonged use may cause peripheral neuropathy.

Aminoquinolines



Aminoquinolines (eg, chloroquine, hydroxychloroquine, amodiaquine, primaquine) have activity against Plasmodium species (malaria).  Plasmodium parasites digest hemoglobin in erythrocytes, releasing heme.  Because free heme is toxic, the parasite polymerizes it into nontoxic hemozoin.  Aminoquinolines prevent the polymerization of free heme, which results in parasite death.  Drug resistance related to individual aminoquinolines and the adverse effects of the various agents are described below:



  • Chloroquine:  Generally avoided in areas where P falciparum is endemic due to widespread drug resistance.  Common adverse effects include gastrointestinal upset, pruritus, and retinopathy (prolonged use/higher doses).
  • Hydroxychloroquine:  Has a similar profile to chloroquine but with a lower risk of retinopathy with prolonged use.  It is often used for rheumatologic diseases (eg, rheumatoid arthritis, lupus) due to immunomodulatory effects (eg, inhibition of toll-like receptors, reduced cytokine production, antithrombotic effects).  It is not considered a first-line treatment for malaria.
  • Amodiaquine:  Has activity against chloroquine-resistant P falciparum; however, due to the risk for agranulocytosis and hepatotoxicity, it is not generally used as a monotherapy.  Instead, it is often combined with other antimalarial agents as part of artemisinin-based combination therapy (eg, artesunate plus amodiaquine).
  • Primaquine:  Has some unique features not shared with other aminoquinolines.  This medication has activity against P vivax and P ovale hypnozoites (dormant hepatic forms) but has no activity against intraerythrocytic parasites.  In addition, it is gametocidal (prevents transmission) for P falciparum.  Primaquine must be avoided in patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency due to the risk for severe hemolysis; therefore, G6PD testing must be performed prior to use.

Artemisinins



Artemisinins (eg, artesunate, artemether, arteether) treat malaria.  They are derived from the leaves of the Chinese sweet wormwood plant (Artemisia annua) and consist of a sesquiterpene lactone with an endoperoxide bridge.  Iron or heme in the Plasmodium food vacuole activates the artemisinin by breaking the endoperoxide bridge, which generates free radicals and kills the parasite.  The drug works more rapidly than other antimalarials, killing parasites within 1-2 asexual cycles (48 hr).  It also has activity against gametocytes, which reduces transmission risk.



Due to their short half-life, and in order to prevent the development of drug resistance, artemisinins are generally combined with other medications to ensure parasite eradication as part of artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) (eg, artemether + lumefantrine, artesunate + amodiaquine, artesunate + mefloquine).  ACT is considered first-line therapy for uncomplicated and severe P falciparum infection; intravenous artesunate is the treatment of choice for severe malaria.  Resistance to artemisinins is localized (eg, Southeast Asia, East Africa) and has resulted in delayed parasite clearance, but not treatment failure.



This class of medications is generally well tolerated, but delayed hemolysis (days or weeks later) can occur in patients who receive intravenous therapy.

Antifolates



Antifolates (eg, sulfonamides, pyrimethamine, proguanil, dapsone) inhibit the enzymatic conversion of p-aminobenzoic acid â†’ dihydrofolic acid â†’ tetrahydrofolic acid, which is required for purine, deoxythymidine triphosphate, and methionine synthesis (

image 2
).  Blockade of these enzymatic steps impairs DNA synthesis.  Antifolates are used in the treatment of a wide array of bacterial and some parasitic (eg, malaria, Toxoplasma) infections.  However, point mutations in dihydropteroate synthase or dihydrofolate reductase can cause resistance.



Although antifolates selectively target bacterial and protozoal enzymes, host cells also require tetrahydrofolic acid for DNA synthesis and repair.  Therefore, this class of medication can cause adverse effects, particularly in rapidly dividing host cells.  This can result in bone marrow suppression (eg, anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia) and gastrointestinal mucosal issues (eg, mucositis, stomatitis).  Rash and hepatotoxicity can also occur.

Miltefosine



Miltefosine was developed as an antineoplastic agent but is now used to treat some parasitic infections (eg, Leishmania, N fowleri).  This drug is a synthetic alkylphosphocholine that inserts into lipid bilayers and disrupts membrane integrity; it also interferes with lipid-dependent cell signaling pathways.  It is teratogenic; women who take the medication must use reliable contraception during and after treatment (half-life is 30 days).  Although adverse effects are common (eg, kidney, gastrointestinal), it is much better tolerated than older compounds used for leishmaniasis (discussed in the next section).

Heavy metal compounds



This class of medications (eg, melarsoprol, sodium stibogluconate) contains toxic metal elements (eg, arsenic, antimony).  They disrupt parasite metabolism by binding enzymatic sulfhydryl groups, which inactivates key proteins and causes oxidative stress.  However, because they act nonselectively, the risk of host cell toxicity (eg, encephalopathy, peripheral neuropathy, mucositis, hepatotoxicity, pancreatitis, cardiotoxicity) is high.  Therefore, they are typically used only under medical supervision when other agents have failed.  Melarsoprol can be used for CNS trypanosomiasis; sodium stibogluconate is used for leishmaniasis.

Benznidazole and nifurtimox



These nitroheterocyclic compounds treat Chagas disease (T cruzi) by generating reactive oxygen species (nitro radicals) in the parasites.  Benznidazole has fewer adverse effects than nifurtimox, but both medications can cause neuropathy and gastrointestinal issues (eg, nausea/vomiting).

Other agents



  • Nitazoxanide:  Broad-spectrum antiparasitic agent that inhibits the pyruvate-ferredoxin oxidoreductase pathway in anaerobic metabolism.  It is primarily used in the treatment of Giardia and Cryptosporidium.
  • Paromomycin:  Aminoglycoside antibiotic that inhibits the 30S ribosomal subunit in prokaryotic cells, which impairs protein synthesis.  It is used as a luminal agent for E histolytica (in conjunction with metronidazole).

Protozoa are a diverse group of eukaryotic organisms with complex life cycles.  Treatment often targets a single step in the protozoan life cycle.  The major antiprotozoal medications are summarized in this table (
